document.title: Mathematics Standards of Learning for Virginia Public Schools

F1FEA706FA86426BBAFD5B6690221655.description:
Investigate and explain the connection between two different representations of the same
increasing or decreasing pattern.

D6B4BA0C282E480D9B2BF082E710997A.description: Create increasing and decreasing patterns using objects, pictures, numbers, and number lines.

9AB5A3242EE940A5BE5F1BD8FC697F90.description: Solve contextual problems that involve identifying, describing, and extending patterns.

C54C362D56E547DB94CAE42622EE96E6.description:
Analyze an increasing or decreasing pattern and generalize the change to extend the pattern or
identify missing terms using various representations.

B51E2549CB414CBFA7D1AB2A32B4EC00.description:
Identify and describe increasing and decreasing patterns using various representations (e.g.,
objects, pictures, numbers, number lines).

2C57D4288BBC44C188107F5574F50DE4.description:
The student will identify, describe, extend, and create increasing and decreasing
patterns (limited to addition and subtraction of whole numbers), including those in
context, using various representations.

39B9F87B58E44CC1BA22C4F0D30BCA3B.description:
solve one- and two-step addition and subtraction problems using data from pictographs
and bar graphs.

7D2B7A5F97CE45FA93E4019C514FC9C3.description:
use characteristics of the data to draw conclusions about the data and make predictions
based on the data (e.g., it is unlikely that a third grader would like hard boiled eggs); and

0C2086D94BB2471E99D704AB5D289A63.description: make inferences about data represented in pictographs and bar graphs;

F7E844B306C24C9DBB7F7C8F6343E0D8.description:
identify parts of the data that have special characteristics, including categories with the
greatest, the least, or the same (e.g., most students prefer scrambled eggs);

026CCFFD8AC440CFB36A02C030C5A578.description:
describe the categories of data and the data as a whole (e.g., data were collected on
preferred ways to cook or prepare eggs - scrambled, fried, hard boiled, and egg salad);

F4B5C5CBF8D54AE68149359B867D397D.description:
Analyze data represented in pictographs and bar graphs, and communicate results orally and
in writing:

0880D9919471493797164E5BFE64032D.description:
Organize and represent a data set using bar graphs with a title and labeled axes, with and
without the use of technology tools. Determine and use an appropriate scale (increments
limited to multiples of 1, 2, 5 or 10).

14F9A11D9AC347E5A31F63CBE09D1B3C.description:
Organize and represent a data set using pictographs that include an appropriate title, labeled
axes, and key. Each pictograph symbol should represent 1, 2, 5 or 10 data points.

70929B6C07984AC981A135856CB75DDD.description:
Determine the data needed to answer a formulated question and collect or acquire existing
data (limited to 30 or fewer data points for no more than eight categories) using various
methods (e.g., polls, observations, tallies).

31567397645E447AACF8AC6B15BD5A3A.description: Formulate questions that require the collection or acquisition of data.

F8B6327C117C4831BB4B972E3B8CFFA8.description:
Subdivide a three-sided or four-sided polygon into no more than three parts and name the
resulting polygons.

5920BF751E894CC48BA6FC5989E23990.description:
Combine no more than three polygons, where each has three or four sides, and name the
resulting polygon (triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, octagons).

000CB541132543C7BCD219C1835C1C3E.description: Classify and compare polygons (triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, octagons).

E46D1A0710704A0685C82E957B0D4E09.description:
Identify and name examples of polygons (triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons,
octagons) in the environment.

B99988A08F6A40BBB275C7F0EAF2E819.description:
Identify and describe triangles, quadrilaterals, pentagons, hexagons, and octagons in various
orientations, with and without contexts.

4CFEBC87DF4D44F3979DF473C11F01F4.description: Classify figures as polygons or not polygons and justify reasoning.

969A8F61B5A4465BBEC01BBEEC658D2C.description:
Describe a polygon as a closed plane figure composed of at least three line segments that do
not cross.

8B91356B51C94360AD6D250368C03821.description:
The student will identify, describe, classify, compare, combine, and subdivide
polygons.

98D3D6AB305E4119B0FB1B6DDF6EB52D.description:
the ending time and the amount of elapsed time in one-hour increments, determine the
starting time.

C2906936950F470992DAB9E60A089388.description:
the starting time and amount of elapsed time in one-hour increments, determine the ending
time; or

5B61C46CDE65436984F1F996A8480632.description: the starting time and the ending time, determine the amount of time that has elapsed;

49CF3A78EE954A1DA8D88B66BBD7DF03.description:
Solve single-step contextual problems involving elapsed time in one-hour increments, within
a 12-hour period (within a.m. or within p.m.) when given:

8B4F6FCDB4624220B824EC0D3E1EDAB5.description:
Match a written time (e.g., 4:38, 7:09, 12:51) to the time shown on analog and digital clocks
to the nearest minute.

2C47ED9BCA504FDD9A3513958ACB9017.description: Tell and write time to the nearest minute, using analog and digital clocks.

4DBFD7ECBBD9481C8845176D72C2181B.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the concept of time to the nearest
minute and solve single-step contextual problems involving elapsed time in one-hour
increments within a 12-hour period.

0A651A22948B451F8D370C7951563829.description:
given the lengths of all sides of a polygon (with no more than six sides), determine its
perimeter and justify the measurement.

9AD3997BEAB24DF5863B6EE6CE73FAA4.description:
estimate and measure the distance around a polygon (with no more than six sides) to
determine the perimeter and justify the measurement; and

DBE1BC4FA7304FA5AF37A8B36E964B47.description: describe and give examples of perimeter as a measurement in contextual situations;

FC45F733675C4FE3B8AAD29BE8C0E41C.description: Solve problems, including those in context, involving perimeter:

50C70EC632F44490AA2FB760E45E6C4A.description:
estimate and determine the area of a given surface by counting the number of square units,
describe the measurement (using the number and unit) and justify the measurement.

120AAF3664D14BF1967C395BEA8DA778.description: describe and give examples of area as a measurement in contextual situations; and

6DF3768AF97F49519AE02BC22C918FFB.description: Solve problems, including those in context, involving area:

F6D6002EF2E3445D9134452C95F0CDDC.description:
The student will use multiple representations to estimate and solve problems, including
those in context, involving area and perimeter (in both U.S. Customary and metric
units).

3326DF6212DB42A3B19B45D68D8CC27E.description: Compare estimates of length, weight/mass, or liquid volume with the actual measurements.

2DC8DB79D75A45A286EA5AA671017A30.description:
liquid volume to the nearest U.S. Customary unit (cup, pint, quart, gallon) and metric unit
(liter).

807979B7C37C45D3B7E61D78F5C310AB.description:
weight/mass of an object to the nearest U.S. Customary unit (pound) and metric unit
(kilogram); and

C1E807F3CA2D47C5A877559CE6FE9B47.description:
length of an object to the nearest U.S. Customary unit (1
2
inch, inch, foot, yard) and metric
unit (centimeter, meter);

8D33EF798C5742F8B39BBB775C6DBC41.description:
Justify whether an estimate or an exact measurement is needed for a contextual situation and
choose an appropriate unit.

62F0061789E34FDB80BBFD5B228CBA15.description:
The student will reason mathematically using standard units (U.S. Customary and
metric) with appropriate tools to estimate and measure objects by length, weight/mass,
and liquid volume to the nearest half or whole unit.

E3CDAC7B98484670B2A9250C0FD4B312.description:
Create an equation to represent the mathematical relationship between equivalent expressions
using multiplication and/or division facts through 10 × 10 (e.g., 4 × 3 = 14 - 2, 35 ÷ 5 = 1 ×
7).

D666743E81D84D26895CAAF4B51EC431.description:
Recall with automaticity the multiplication facts through 10 × 10 and the corresponding
division facts.

57B8ABDDA0554E72A1F35510A820C558.description:
Represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step contextual problems that involve
multiplication and division of whole numbers through 10 × 10.

4F0FFBB649B84661BC2DEF56977B9464.description:
Demonstrate fluency with multiplication facts through 10 × 10 by applying reasoning
strategies (e.g., doubling, add-a-group, subtract-a-group, near squares, and inverse
relationships).

56419F467FB84B20A30294AA3EFF804D.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., place value, the properties of multiplication and/or addition) when
multiplying and dividing whole numbers.

DFAC822925684D8B9024F704B28073BC.description:
Use inverse relationships to write the related facts connected to a given model for
multiplication and division of whole numbers through 10 × 10.

D4C188D9498F4F5488D03DBE09AABCCB.description:
Represent multiplication and division of whole numbers through 10 × 10, including in a
contextual situation, using a variety of approaches and models (e.g., repeated
addition/subtraction, equal-sized groups/sharing, arrays, equal jumps on a number line, using
multiples to skip count).

91AF8A0F709E49FAAE8B1629051EE36D.description:
The student will recall with automaticity multiplication and division facts through 10 ×
10; and represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step contextual problems using
multiplication and division with whole numbers.

1823B2F6CC5C436B8E4C76176C7256D4.description:
Represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and multistep contextual problems
involving addition and subtraction with whole numbers where addends and minuends do not
exceed 1,000.

371695405F1E4FF891DF326F6DFDED7E.description:
Identify and use the appropriate symbol to distinguish between expressions that are equal and
expressions that are not equal (e.g., 256 - 13 = 220 + 23; 457 + 100 ≠ 557 + 100).

6DC969D93964424EAA59D1D6395BB9FA.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., place value, properties of addition, other number relationships) and
algorithms, including the standard algorithm, to determine the sum or difference of two whole
numbers where addends and minuends do not exceed 1,000.

106D1E7EDF544523B843B389EF59BDAE.description:
Apply strategies (e.g., rounding to the nearest 10 or 100, using compatible numbers, using
other number relationships) to estimate a solution for single-step or multistep addition or
subtraction problems, including those in context, where addends or minuends do not exceed
1,000.

629A1B3E89F24ECC9E4B1DDEE18ADC98.description:
Determine and justify whether an estimate or an exact answer is appropriate when solving
single-step and multistep contextual problems involving addition and subtraction, where
addends and minuends do not exceed 1,000.

C532A547834740B88DBE441A628E6F63.description:
The student will estimate, represent, solve, and justify solutions to single-step and
multistep problems, including those in context, using addition and subtraction with
whole numbers where addends and minuends do not exceed 1,000.

5D1CABA878DB4B1180A6777431805761.description:
Solve contextual problems to make change from $5.00 or less by using counting on or
counting back strategies with concrete or pictorial models.

5681D4F3DF3D4157A363B363EB440CB1.description:
Compare the values of two sets of coins or two sets of bills and coins, up to $5.00, with words
(greater than, less than, equal to) and/or symbols (>, <, =) using concrete or pictorial models.

E030892DF31B45A7B0F741AD260490F6.description:
Construct a set of bills and coins to total a given amount of money whose value is $5.00 or
less.

1279C64A9FFF4AC584CBFB4D71114F6A.description: Determine the value of a collection of bills and coins whose total is $5.00 or less.

6DC4DD2D48F74EF7A6B614EE5DB12F96.description:
The student will solve problems, including those in context, that involve counting,
comparing, representing, and making change for money amounts up to $5.00.

C5234D731E8B4D84A31398457D88D0C8.description:
Represent equivalent fractions with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, or 10, using region/area
models and length models.

2FA3B1E04C364D299C0CD53A6FED3340.description:
Compare two fractions (proper or improper) and/or mixed numbers with like denominators of
2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, and 10 (e.g., 3
6
<
4
6
) using words (greater than, less than, equal to) and/or
symbols (>, <, =), using area/region models, length models, and without models.

B0F2D8C09B63450FBEB3931E105F7B4F.description:
Compare two fractions (proper or improper) and/or mixed numbers with like numerators of 2,
3, 4, 5, 6, 8, and 10 (e.g., 2
3
>
2
8
) using words (greater than, less than, equal to) and/or symbols
(>, <, =), using area/region models, length models, and without models.

89F3755A61AD4D3292CF53289DEABF53.description:
Compare a fraction, less than or equal to one, to the benchmarks of 0, 1
2
, and 1 using
area/region models, length models, and without models.

3D82AD21833547C3818D9FAE611ABF0C.description:
Compose and decompose fractions (proper and improper) with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6,
8, and 10 in multiple ways (e.g., 7
4
=
4
4
+ 3
4
or
4
6
=
3
6
+ 1
6
=
2
6
+ 2
6
) with models.

60F7C6D5B29D4811BA5C3B09B7916726.description:
Use a model of a fraction greater than one to count the fractional parts to name and write it as
an improper fraction and as a mixed number (e.g., 1
4
,
2
4
,
3
4
,
4
4
,
5
4
= 1 1
4
).

E059CFF8EE5E4850A2D38F9FD1439926.description: Identify a fraction represented by a model as the sum of unit fractions.

D22C63EB5D0C459CAD977F6804E0F759.description: length models (e.g., paper fraction strips, fraction bars, rods, number lines); and

338B0ED92B294B9BA710C32A26CA0125.description: region/area models (e.g., pie pieces, pattern blocks, geoboards);

199F2F34658F4AE19CEBFEF96CD09F9E.description:
Represent, name, and write a given fraction (proper or improper) or mixed number with
denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, and 10 using:

803E10F3E8E34C7B811559E7C45598E3.description:
The student will use mathematical reasoning and justification to represent and compare
fractions (proper and improper) and mixed numbers with denominators of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6,
8, and 10), including those in context.

F65F4E8780164D68A632E69CD55CDF72.description:
Order up to three whole numbers, each 9,999 or less, represented with and without models,
from least to greatest and greatest to least.

04DD346C2D6B4997A540BBD1106A63D8.description:
Compare two whole numbers, each 9,999 or less, using symbols (>, <, =, ≠) and/or words
(greater than, less than, equal to, not equal to), with and without models.

14CE57BB7BB8450F986BEBA7D4BED1E1.description:
The student will demonstrate an understanding of the base 10 system to compare and
order whole numbers up to 9,999.

2361B3FB91A3429E9A092D8F49EAEE6A.description:
Compose, decompose, and represent numbers up to 9,999 in multiple ways, according to
place value (e.g., 256 can be 1 hundred, 14 tens, 16 ones, but also 25 tens, 6 ones), with and
without models.

E2401E28E5F74B2E8C4BA889BE228B62.description:
Apply patterns within the base 10 system to determine and communicate, orally and in written
form, the place and value of each digit in a six-digit whole number (e.g., in 165,724, the 5
represents 5 thousands and its value is 5,000).

E5060D249A65444C98FEC5F57C6DADE0.description: Read and write six-digit whole numbers in standard form, expanded form, and word form.

9DBAD935B1F14EA7BACD25186A6EB056.description:
The student will use place value understanding to read, write, and determine the place
and value of each digit in a whole number, up to six digits, with and without models.
